description: From Middle English lous, lows, lowse, from Old English lūs, from Proto-West Germanic *lūs, from Proto-Germanic *lūs, from Proto-Indo-European *lewH-.
See also West Frisian lûs, Dutch luis, German Low German Luus, German Laus); also Welsh llau (“lice”), Tocharian B luwo, maybe Sanskrit यूका (yūkā).

entries.meaning: A small parasitic wingless insect of the order Psocodea.
(colloquial, dated, not usually used in plural form) A contemptible person; one who is deceitful or causes harm.
examples: He said: "Thanks, friend; but you're wasting your time. You better warn Crocker. If that louse makes a play for me, he'll get hit with Chicago lightning!"

verbs.description: louse (third-person singular simple present louses, present participle lousing, simple past and past participle loused)

entries.meaning: To remove lice from; to delouse.
